thread.title: Ravensthorpe cut off after WA floods wash away bridge into town - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Ravensthorpe cut off after WA floods wash away bridge into town - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Mark Bennett
title: Ravensthorpe cut off after WA floods wash away bridge into town - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Ravensthorpe 6346 
Flood-damaged roads in Western Australia's south could be reopened within days. 
Main Roads said it was confident the South Coast Highway between Ravensthorpe and Esperance and would be opened to traffic by early next week. 
Bridges and roads were damaged by flood waters a week ago isolating Ravensthorpe from Albany and Esperance. 
Businesses in Ravensthorpe have been hit hard by the loss of tourist trade and the limited supplies getting through. 
The regional manager for Main Roads, Andrew Duffield, said crews were gradually restoring the roads and crossings that link Ravensthorpe to Munglinup east of Esperance and hoped to open that section of the highway under speed restrictions within a few days. 
"The Jerdacuttup River Bridge, the Hatfield River crossing and the Oldfield River bridge have proved problematic with deep scouring of the roads and supports to the bridges," Mr Duffield said. 
"We have been able to effect some repairs to allow traffic to the First Quantum Minerals mine site." 
West of Ravensthorpe on South Coast Highway, the Philips River bridge was ripped from its foundations at the height of the flood and now lies on the riverbank 80 metres downstream. Photo: The Phillips River Bridge washed 80m down stream by floods. (ABC News: Mark Bennett) 
To get to Albany motorists now have to take an 80 kilometre diversion on dirt roads. 
It will be weeks before Main Roads will be able to complete a temporary causeway to take east west traffic across the Philips River while a replacement bridge is built. 
The damage bill was estimated to be around $20 million, but that has been constantly revised as the full cost of repairing the 840km of damaged roads in the south east region comes to light. Tourist trade and supply route cut to town 
Ravensthorpe has been deserted by the tourists, with the town's caravan park completely empty. 
Businesses supplied by trucks are desperate for normal delivery services to resume. 
At the hardware store jerry cans to store fuel have flown of the shelf, along with tarpaulins and roof fixing screws to repair the damage from the rain. 
Normally the caravaners and passing traffic are the lifeblood of the town. 
Lily Prosser says the floods have been a disaster for her fledging cafe business which she opened just six weeks ago. Photo: Cafe owner Lily Prosser relies on the tourist traffic that is not coming through the town. (ABC News: Mark Bennett) 
"It's been terrible, the whole town has been suffering, we've had no tourists coming in or stopping at all," Ms Prosser said. 
"We are in the middle of nowhere and there's not a lot of business here as it is, so when the traffic stops the business stops when there's nothing coming through. 
"Even though we've got two mine sites here they really don't come into town at all and we need to rely on the tourists so everyone is struggling." Maintenance teams must mobilise 
The federal Member for O'Connor, Rick Wilson, inspected the damage yesterday with shire CEO Ian Fitzgerald. 
"The really important thing is for the shires to be able to get an exemption under the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery funding that was announced by the state and federal governments on Wednesday," Mr Fitzgerald said. 
"Currently local governments are not allowed to use their maintenance crews under the relief package but here there is so much damage to local roads that they need urgent attention. 
"The federal minister has offered an exemption to the West Australian Government and we are hoping very much that the WA Government will take that up. 
"We spoke to farmers who have livestock on other blocks who can't check them to see if fences are still intact and whether their animals are still there and need feeding." 
He said it was important for the council to be allowed to get the local networks open for the farmers. 
"What we've seen here today is extraordinary and the local farmers are going to need a lot of help to get back on their feet," Mr Fitzgerald said.
